snippet: While he had been giving out bills one day at the shop door, a man who had been carelessly looking in at one of the windows approached the shop door, and pretended to try the texture ofthe cloth of an over-coat there displayed. Then, while Slogan's back was turned, he tugged down the coat, darted in to an entry leading down to Blair Street, and disappeared. Slogan did not run well, as the want of the arm interfered in some way with his balance, but he nevertheless managed to scramble and fall down the stair after the thief, and with a desperate spurt made up to him at the foot of the street.

snippet: Once or twice I thought that Morton appeared less hopeful, but the real change was as sudden as it was effectual. He had ventured forth from his mean lodging in Blair Street one sunny forenoon, and was quietly slipping round the Tron to a shop in the High Street, when Altryde and Nell turned gaily up from the North Bridge, arm in arm, as if going to the Castle on a pleasure stroll. Morton would as soon have expected the sun to drop at his feet, and he staggered back almost fainting.

snippet: In this building alone could the Scriptures be printed, and from nowhere else in Scotland could they be issued. Hence, on the title-page of all oldish Bibles we see the names, " Sir David Hunter Blair and M. T. Bruce, Printers to the King's most Excellent Majesty;" and we are inclined to think that the street in which the building stands takes its name of Blair Street from the father of the baronet who held the monopoly.
